+Joseph Barrel Jehovah's Witnesses from an organizational perspective are 
focused on the printing and distribution of Bible-based books and 
magazines. The Watchtower and Awake! being the primary journals. In the 
USA, "selling" a religious magazine or book can run afoul of laws that 
govern tax-exempt charities. Jimmy Swaggart Ministry ran into this problem. 
Thus nowadays, JWs, like other groups, tend to use the word "donation" and 
specify no specific amount. Because the cost of producing printed 
literature is high, the organization has for the last few years been 
stressing online content at jw.org and have done several things to reduce 
the number of pages that must be printed each month.

An individual Witness comes to your door, because, that is the demand of 
the faith. There is group pressure to "preach" in this manner. As far as I 
was ever aware, all members, including those in leadership positions engage 
in this work. Some of the Witnesses you encounter are sincere and zealous 
in this effort -- they really believe they have the truth and you need to 
hear it. Others though may have doubts and nonetheless feel obliged to tag 
along.

I always recommend being kind -- you never know how far a smile and 
kind-word might go. On the other hand, unless you already wish to become 
one of Jehovah's Witnesses, I recommend against accepting their literature 
or an offer of a Bible study. These are tools designed not to teach 
objective truth, but rather to indoctrinate in the belief system of the 
Witnesses.

+Monk Monk 
There are two aspects of "governing body." First is simply the legal 
requirements of incorporating a non-profit society. Such entities have 
governing bodies and voting members. Among Jehovah's Witnesses the annual 
meeting actually serves this legal requirement. Second, and perhaps more 
important, the men who make up the governing body of Jehovah's Witnesses 
make claims of being directed by God and serving spiritual food at the 
proper time. They also claim the identity of the 'faithful and discreet 
slave' (see Matthew 24:45 and The Watchtower of July 15, 2013, page 20).

This is all a fair bit different than what one finds in Acts 15 where the 
circumcision issue was debated. You'll note anyone can read the details of 
this -- it is right there in the Bible. In contrast, ordinary members do 
not have access to the discussions of the governing body of Jehovah's 
Witnesses. And while Acts 21:18 makes mention of 'older men' and Paul, 
nowhere do you see them making claims of being an exclusive channel that 
one must heed for spiritual health.

Of course, the leadership of Jehovah's Witnesses claim "apostates" spread 
"false teaching" but all the word "apostate" means is "stand away from." 
Jehovah's Witnesses, in that context, are themselves "apostates" in that 
they stand away from nominal Christian doctrine, such as Trinity. If the 
Trinity is correct, then that would make Witnesses the false teacher. 
Personally, I continue to believe strong support for the Trinity doctrine 
is lacking in New Testament writing. However...

The doctrinal focus of Jehovah's Witnesses on "Jehovah" is decidedly at 
odds with the New Testament focus on Jesus. If we heed the available 
evidence (i.e the oldest extant copies of NT scripture) we would be 
compelled to conclude that Jesus did not make reference to "Jehovah", nor 
did other NT writers (the closest one gets is at Revelation 19, where "Jah" 
appears within "Hallelujah"). Instead the focus is entirely on Jesus. Even 
when God is mentioned, it is with reference to Jesus, often as 'the son of 
God.'
